verb.description: Drive or force (a liquid, especially a drug or vaccine) into a person or animal's body with a syringe or similar device.
examples: the doctor injected a painkilling drug

verb.description: Introduce (something) into a passage, cavity, or solid material under pressure.
examples: inject the foam and allow it to expand

verb.description: Introduce (a new or different element) into something, especially as a boost or interruption.
examples: she tried to inject scorn into her tone

verb.description: Place (a spacecraft or other object) into an orbit or trajectory.
examples: many meteoroids are injected into hyperbolic orbits

origin: Late 16th century (in the sense throw or cast on something): from Latin inject- thrown in, from the verb inicere, from in- into + jacere throw.
